intro: Chamissoa acuminata var. maximiliani, commonly known as the Maximilian's chamissoa, is a perennial plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Asteraceae family and is characterized by its narrow, grass-like leaves and clusters of small, yellowish flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils in open habitats such as slopes and meadows. It is adapted to arid conditions and has a shallow root system that helps it survive in dry environments. The species is named in honor of the German botanist and explorer August von Kotzebue, who was associated with the expedition of Maximilian von Pulsch.
